title: Question 15
prompt: What information would best argue against Maggie’s stance that Japanese-American internment prevented another surprise attack?
description: Click the <u>one best answer</u> to each question.
feedback:
The question asks for an argument that opposes Maggie’s stance. Her argument is that no Japanese surprise attacks followed Pearl Harbor, and therefore the internment worked. The flaw in the argument is that there may be other reasons why the Japanese did not attack the U.S. again. The correct answer states that no interned Japanese Americans were convicted of espionage. The implication of this information is that the American government had no proof that Japanese spies were among those interned. If the internees were not spies, the internment was unlikely to prevent another attack. This answer logically argues against Maggie’s statement.

Argument: After all, there wasn’t another Japanese surprise attack, was there? It must have worked.

Counter Argument: No Japanese Americans who were arrested or held were later convicted of espionage. If no internees were spies, the internment could not have prevented an attack.
